title-group.article-title: Impact of Psychiatric Diagnoses on Length of Stay and Mortality After Rib Fracture

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Surgery. Division of Trauma Surgery, Acute Care Surgery, Critical Care, and Burns, MetroHealth Medical Center, Cleveland, Ohio, USA
2Department of Surgery, University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, Cleveland, Ohio, USA
3Case Western Reserve University, Department of Population and Quantitative Health Sciences, Cleveland, Ohio, USA

fn.p: All authors were involved in the conception or design of this work. SKK and CWT collected data and performed statistical analysis. All authors drafted and revised the abstract. All authors drafted the manuscript. All authors designed and created figures and tables. All authors edited and critically reviewed the final manuscript.

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Vanessa P. Ho MD MPH, MetroHealth Medical Center, Division of Trauma Surgery, Acute Care Surgery, Critical Care, and Burns, 2500 MetroHealth Drive, Cleveland, OH 44109, Fax: (216) 778-1351, vho@metrohealth.org

Ho MD MPH’s spouse is a consultant for Zimmer Biomet, Atricure, Medtronic, and Astra Zeneca. Sami K. Kishawi MD and Avanti Badrinathan MD have no conflicts of interest or financial ties to disclose.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Concurrent psychiatric diagnoses adversely impact outcomes in surgical patients, but their relationship to patients with rib fracture after trauma is less understood. We hypothesized that psychiatric comorbidity increases hospital length of stay (LOS) and mortality risk after rib fracture.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: The 2017 National Inpatient Sample was queried for adult patients who were admitted with rib fracture after trauma. Psychiatric illness was categorized into 34 psychiatric diagnosis groups (PDG) using Clinical Classifications Software Refined for ICD-10. Outcomes of interest were LOS and mortality. Bivariable analysis determined associations between PDGs, patient demographics, hospital characteristics, and outcomes. Logistic regression was performed to identify adjusted effects on mortality, and linear regression was performed to identify effects on LOS.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of 32,801 patients, median age was 61 years (IQR 46-76) and median LOS was 5 days (IQR 3-9). No PDGs were associated with increased risk of mortality. Concurrent diagnosis of schizophrenia spectrum (Coeff. 3.5, 95% CI 2.7-4.4, p < 0.001) or trauma- or stressor-related (Coeff. 1.6, 95% CI 0.9-2.5, p < 0.001) disorders demonstrated the greatest impact on LOS. Increased odds of death and prolonged hospital stay were also associated with male sex, non-White patient race, and surgery occurring at urban and public hospitals.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Psychiatric comorbidities are not a risk for death after rib fracture. They do, however, impact LOS. Hospital characteristics and patient demographics also impact mortality and LOS. These findings may help guide perioperative patient management.
